settings.text: In times of uncertainty, it is easy for us to become disconnected from our bodies, our breath, our selves. Yoga is a wonderful tool for healing the effects of stress and anxiety, helping us to bring the nervous system back into a place of equilibrium. The poses below can be practised in sequence or on their own and will provide an opportunity for grounding, nurturing and deep relaxation. Allow Chinti & Parker’s Content Manager and resident yoga teacher, Harriet Allmark, to guide you. The sequence was created and shot by Harriet whilst the team have all been working from home.

settings.grid-content:
Great for: Clearing the inner space, connecting to the breath and preparing for your yoga practice.

How to: Find a comfortable seated position where the sit bones are grounded, and the spine is tall. You may like to sit on a folded blanket or cushion to raise the hips. Bring one hand to your heart and the other hand to your stomach, relax the shoulders. Begin to tune into the breath, noticing how the chest and belly rise and release on each inhalation and exhalation. Allow the breath to become longer and smoother. Sit here for at least ten breaths.

Great for: Relieving lower back ache after prolonged periods of sitting.

How to: Come to a kneeling position with your knees wider than your hips and your big toes touching.

Place a bolster (a pillow or a stack of folded blankets also works well) lengthways in front of you and rest your torso over it. Release your elbows to the floor and turn your head to one side. Relax into the support beneath you and bring your attention to your breath. Stay for as long as feels comfortable. Turn your head in the opposite direction halfway through.

settings.title: Cat / Cow
settings.text:
Great for: Awakening the spine at any time of the day.

How to: Begin in all fours, with your shoulders stacked over wrists and hips over knees. On an inhale, dip your stomach toward the ground, broaden your collarbones, let the sit bones spread. Press into the hands, shins and tops of the feet. Lift the chin a little, gaze beyond the short edge of your mat.

On an exhale, round up through the spine, hollowing the belly and gently tucking the chin. Keep pressing through the hands, shins and tops of the feet.

Continue to move like this, in time with your own breath.

settings.grid-content:
Great for: Stretching the shoulders, armpits and chest after spending time at your desk.

How to: Come to a kneeling position. Reach your right arm upwards, bend the elbow and place the hand in between the shoulder blades, palm facing down. Extend your left arm out

to the side and point the thumb downwards. Bend the left elbow and place the back of the left hand onto the back. You can clasp the fingertips or your top, but don’t overreach. Right elbow

points up, left elbow points down. Gaze forward. Stay for three to six breaths. Repeat on the opposite side.

Great for: Stretching the thighs and groins, opening the chest.

How to: Begin in all fours. Step your right foot in between your hands. Bring both hands to your right thigh, stacking your right knee above your right ankle. Square your hips to the front of your mat. Press your right foot and left shin into the mat. Sink the hips as you raise your arms, palms face inwards. Stretch through the arms. Stay for three breaths before repeating on the second side.

Great for: Stretching the thighs and groins, opening the chest.

How to: Lie on your stomach, bend your elbows and place your forearms onto the ground. Your shoulders should be stacked over your elbows. Spread your fingers and press down. Roll your inner thighs upwards, draw your navel towards your spine and press into the tops of the feet. Energetically pull your forearms backwards to open through the chest and collarbones. Gaze is forwards. Stay for three to six breaths.

settings.grid-title: Reclining Hand to Big Toe Pose
settings.grid-content:
Great for: Stretching the hamstrings. 

How to: Take a strap – you can improvise with a scarf or a tie – around the ball of your right foot and press the foot up towards the sky. The left leg can either be bent with the foot placed onto the mat or stretched long down the mat. As you hold the strap, allow the collarbones to broaden and the shoulder blades to soften. Use the breath to help lengthen the lifted leg. Stay for three to six breaths. Switch to the other side.

Great for: Releasing tension in the spine and lower back after long periods of sitting. 

How to: Lie on your back. Bend both knees and pull them in towards your chest. Slowly lower the knees over to the right side, knees are stacked. Extend your arms out to the sides, palms facing up, shoulders relax. Gaze over the left hand, twisting through the entire spine. Stay there for three - six breaths. Repeat on the second side.

Great for: Releasing the lower back and sacrum, opening the hips. 

How to: Lie on your back, bend your knees and bring them towards your chest. Reach your arms inside your legs and hold onto the outsides of your flexed feet. Shins are perpendicular to the ground; knees move towards your armpits. Reach your sit bones down. Gaze is soft. Gently rock from side to side to massage the lower back. Stay for three – six breaths.

Great for: Fatigue, anxiety and insomnia, soothing the nervous system.   

How to: Sit with one side of your body to the wall and then, rolling onto your back, gently swing your legs up the wall. This will help you to get nice and close to the wall, so you are fully supported. Either bring your hands to your belly or reach the arms out wide. Allow yourself to feel supported by the ground. You may like to place a folded blanket beneath your head for support; the back of the neck is long, the eyes close and the chin gently draws down. Stay for as long as feels comfortable.
